subject: Re: [junit] Testing API where order in which methods are invoked matters

messageBody:
On Friday 24 June 2005 13:24, arnabgupta2000 wrote:
> Hello,
>
> I am new to JUnit and in need for a solution. I have written a
> library
> of which I need to test one class. The methods exposed by this class
> cannot be called randomly but by following some rules. For example,
> there is a method "Connect" which must be invoked before any other
> method is called. There are additional calls that are related. For
> example "ChangeHeaders" makes temporary change to some data (after
> some business logic verification), however this must be followed by a
> call to "SaveChanges" to persist this data. Whatever I have read
> about
> JUnit seems to indicate that the test methods in my test class can be
> called in any order by the JUnit framework. Is there any way (a
> pattern) to get around this issue ? Thanks much in advance..

Yes, the methods in your test class are not (necessarily) called
in any particular order. This is a feature. Each test method should
be unrelated to the others - otherwise it's too hard to eg move
them around for greater expressivity, call only the failing when
when you want to isolate a problem, &co.

There are at least two things you can do:

(a) Ensure that each test uses its own object (easy) and that it
runs the piece of lifecycle you're interested in to
completion.

(b) Refactor so that this object-state dependency is reduced
(preferably to zero).

For (b) I'd start by fixing the `connect` problem: if nothing
can be done withotu a connection, I'd have a more factory-like
object with a `connect` method; calling this delivers a connected
object.

For Change/Save, I'd just have the test do the Change and then
the Save in the same testXXX() method.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
It's called *extreme* programming, not *stupid* programming.
